questions.text: A 62 year old man comes to emergency at 4.00 am with severe epistaxis and high blood pressure (180/110mm Hg). Management of hypertension started. But the epistaxis could not be controlled on anterior nasal packing and posterior nasal packing. What is the next best management of this patient
questions.solution:
• Ligation of vessels in nasal bleeding is reserved for intractable bleeding where the source cannot be located or controlled by anterior or posterior nasal packing.
  • Ligation should be performed as close as possible to the likely bleeding point thus the hierarchy of ligation is: Sphenopalatine artery
    • Internal maxillary artery
    • External carotid artery
    • Anterior/posterior ethmoidal artery
  • Endonasal endoscopic sphenopalatine artery ligation (ESPAL) conforms to the ideal of controlling the bleed as close as possible to its nasal source.
  • The sphenopalatine artery is the main supply of the nasal cavity and thus the most logical target for ligation.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume1; Page 1177

choices.text: Discontinue oxymetazoline and start steroid nasal spray

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents with complaints of chronic nasal congestion. About 2 months earlier, he had an upper respiratory tract infection with rhinorrhea and nasal congestion. Since then he continues to use oxymetazoline nasal twice daily. Physical examination swollen turbinates and no purulent discharge. What is the most appropriate treatment?
questions.solution:
Excessive use of nasal decongestants causes phenomenon called rhinitis medicamentosa, which is described in the clinical scenario.

Rhinitis Medicamentosa

  • Topical decongestant nasal drops are notorious to cause rebound phenomenon.
  • Their excessive use causes rhinitis.
  • It is treated by withdrawal of nasal drops, short course of systemic steroid therapy.
  • Surgical reduction of turbinates may be done in few cases if they have become hypertrophied.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 191

questions.text: An adult patient while having food suddenly develops choking sensation and is unable to speak. What is the immediate management
questions.solution:
• Laryngeal foreign body: A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.
  • The measures consist consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich manoeuvre.
  • These measures should not be done if patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.
  • Heimlich manoeuvre: Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.
  • Cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be done if Heimlich manoeuvre fails.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 367

questions.text: What is the most common source of bleeding during tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
Paratonsillar vein is also known as External Palatine vein/Dennis Browne vein. So, both options A & B are correct.

  • Veins from the tonsils drain into paratonsillar vein which joins the common facial vein and pharyngeal venous plexus
  • Paratonsillar Vein is the most common cause of bleeding during tonsillectomy (primary hemorrhage)
  • M/C arterial cause of bleeding or M/C cause of torrential bleeding during tonsillectomy: Tonsillar branch of facial artery (called as artery of tonsillar haemorrhage)

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume3; Page 635

choices.text: CT scan Nose & Paranasal sinuses with contrast
MRI Nose sinuses and orbit with contrast

questions.text: A young Diabetic patient on with high glyosylated hemoglobin levels has presented to ENT OPD with blood stained nasal discharge, eye swelling, blurring of vision and recent history of loose upper teeth. Which of the following is the first investigation in this case?
questions.solution:
Diabetic patient with uncontrolled sugars presenting with blood stained nasal discharge, eye swelling, blurring of vision and falling of teeth gives suspicion to the diagnosis of Mucormycosis with intraorbital extension. MRI Nose, PNS and orbit will be done as the first investigation on emergency basis to better delineate the soft tissue extent of that & for surgical planning.

  • CECT NOSE PNS will also be done eventually
  • Nasal swab for special fungal stains to detect mucor species will also lead us to diagnosis.

MUCORMYCOSIS

  • It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal.
  • It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.
  • From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain.
  • CECT PNS with orbit or MRI PNS with orbit is done to delineate the extent of disease and tissue destruction and necrosis.
  • MRI Brain is done to detect intracranial extension
  • The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.
  • Typical finding is the presence of a black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.
  • Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.
  • Treatment is by amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 178

questions.text: A 17 year old male patient presented to ENT OPD with the history of nasal obstruction and severe nasal bleeding. The nasal endoscopy picture shows a mass in the choana as given in the image. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A young male with nasal obstruction and severe nasal bleeding and choanal mass points to the diagnosis of JNA (Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiofibroma).

Juvenile Nasopharyngeal Angiopharyngioma (JNA)

  • Profuse, recurrent and spontaneous epistaxis is the most common presentation. Patient may be markedly anaemic due to repeated blood loss.
  • Other clinical features like broadening of nasal bridge, proptosis, swelling of cheek, infratemporal fossa or involvement of IInd, IIIrd, IVth and VIth cranial nerves will depend on the extent of tumour.
  • Diagnosis is mainly clinicoradiological. Biopsy of the tumour is attended with profuse bleeding and is, therefore, avoided.
  • CECT Face shows anterior bowing of posterior wall of maxillary sinus, often called antral sign or Holman-Miller sign, is pathognomic of angiofibroma. It also shows the extent of tumour, bony destruction or displacements.
  • Carotid angiography shows the extent of tumours, its vascularity and feeding vessels which mostly come from the external carotid system. In very large tumours or those with intracranial extension vessels may also come from internal carotid system. Embolization of vessels can be done at this time to decrease bleeding at operation. Feeders from only the external carotid system can be embolized. Resection of tumour should not be delayed beyond 24-48 h of embolization to avoid revascularization from the contralateral side.
  • Surgery is the treatment of choice.

Other options:

  • Inverted papilloma: Usually affects old aged men in the age group of 40-70 years and presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge and epistaxis.
  • Antrochoanal polyp affects young age with mainly nasal obstruction features. Unilateral nasal obstruction is the presenting symptom, obstruction may become bilateral when polyp grows into the nasopharynx and starts obstructing the opposite choana. Severe epistaxis is a rare presentation. On nasal endoscopy, mass appears smooth greyish covered with nasal discharge.
  • Rhinosporidiosis: A chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi. In the nose, the disease presents as a leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in colour and attached to nasal septum or lateral wall. Patient often complaints of blood stained nasal discharge and nasal stuffiness.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 279-81

questions.text: Name the structure marked with straight yellow arrow
questions.solution:
• This is an endoscopic view of nasopharynx showing left side lateral wall of nasopharynx.
  • The straight arrow points towards Fossa of Rosenmuller which lies behind the elevation formed by eustachean tube cartilage in the lateral wall of nasopharynx known as torus tubarius and the opening of ET is shown by curved arrow.
  • Fossa of Rosenmuller is the commonest site for the origin of carcinoma nasopharynx.

Other options:

  • Pyriform sinus is a part of hypopharynx seen during laryngeal examination, on either side of laryngeal inlet
  • The sphenopalatine foramen (SPF) represents an opening on the lateral nasal wall that is present at the articulation between the superior aspect of the vertical portion of the palatine bone and the inferior projection of the sphenoid bone. JNA arises from the superior lip/margin of SPF

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 270-71

questions.text: A adult patient is a known case of bronchial asthma. He has a history of regular medication. The nasal examination shows the presence of nasal polyp. Which drug he is most likely sensitive to?
questions.solution:
• In patients with nasal polyps, 30-71% have been shown to have asthma and there is a direct association between asthma severity and the presence of nasal polyps.
  • Of patients with late-onset asthma, 10-15% develop nasal polyps, with patients generally developing asthma first, then polyps within 9-13 years.
  • This occurs faster in patients with aspirin-induced asthma, about 2 years from the onset of symptoms.
  • Asthma and nasal polyps share the same basic features of eosinophilia, mucus cell hyperplasia, oedema, thickened basal membrane and increased pro-inflammatory mediators, for example cysteine leukotrienes

Aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD, Samter's Triad)

  • Aspirin sensitivity syndrome lies in the inhibition of cycle-oxygenase in the arachidonic acid pathway. By blocking cycle-oxygenase, the arachidonic acid is shunted into lipoxygenase and there is an increased production of leukotrienes.
  • The subsequent decreased prostaglandin E2 leads to mast cell instability with release of histamine.
  • The combination of increased histamine release and increased leukotriene causes increased vascular permeability, leakage from the vascular system and oedema leading to formation of Nasal Polyps.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume1; Page 1039-40

questions.text: An old patient operated for a malignancy. The post operative neck picture neck is given in the picture. which of the following surgical procedure has been done in this case?
questions.solution:
The image in the question shows a permanent stoma of Total Laryngectomy with Provox Tracheo-esophageal prosthesis (TEP).

  • Total laryngectomy is the procedure where the entire larynx including the hyoid bone, pre-epiglottic space, strap muscles and one or more rings of trachea are removed. Pharyngeal wall is repaired and lower tracheal stump sutured to the skin for breathing.
  • Laryngectomy may be combined with block dissection for nodal metastasis.
  • Total laryngectomy is indicated in the following conditions:
    1. T3 lesions (i.e. with cord fixed)
    2. All T4 lesions
    3. Invasion of thyroid or cricoid cartilage
    4. Bilateral arytenoid cartilage involvement
    5. Lesions of posterior commissure
    6. Failure after radiotherapy or conservation surgery
    7. Transglottic cancers, i.e. tumours involving supraglottis and glottis across the ventricle, causing fixation of the vocal cord.
  • Tracheo-esophageal prosthesis (Blom-Singer or Panje) are being used to shunt air from trachea to the oesophagus. The vibrating column of air entering the pharynx is then modulated into speech. They have inbuilt valves which work only in one direction thus preventing problems of aspiration.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 351-53

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the following device?
questions.solution:
• Acute asthmatic attack will lead to laryngospasm/bronchoconstriction, tracheostomy will not help in that.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 360

questions.text: Patient has enlarged tonsils and is unable to swallow. Patient is also complaining of ear pain. Which nerve is the Likely a source of ear pain?
questions.solution:
As ear receives nerve supply from Vth (auriculotemporal branch), IXth (tympanic branch known as Jacobson's nerve) and Xth (auricular branch known as Arnold's nerve) cranial nerves; and from C2 (lesser occipital) and C2 and C3 (greater auricular), pain may be referred from these remote areas.

  • Referred pain to ear via Jacobson's nerve (tympanic branch of IXth cranial nerve) occurs in following conditions:
    1. Oropharynx. Acute tonsillitis, peritonsillar abscess, tonsillectomy. Benign or malignant ulcers of soft palate, tonsil and its pillars.
    2. Base of tongue. Tuberculosis or malignancy.
    3. Elongated styloid process.

Other options:

  1. Arnold's nerve: Auricular branch of vagus nerve. It supplies skin of pinna and EAC. Referred otalgia via Xth cranial nerve arnold's nerve occur in malignancy or ulcerative lesion of vallecula, epiglottis, larynx or laryngopharynx and oesophagus.
  2. Vidian nerve: it is the nerve of pterygoid canal. Parasympathetic nerve fibres supply the nasal glands and control nasal secretion. They come from greater superficial petrosal nerve, travel in the nerve of pterygoid canal (vidian nerve) and reach the sphenopalatine ganglion where they relay before reaching the nasal cavity. They also supply the blood vessels of nose and cause vasodilation.
  3. Nerve of Wrisberg (syn. nervus intermedius). It is a part of facial nerve and carries sensory and parasympathetic fibres.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 143, 154, 510

questions.text: A patient presented with progressive growing swelling from the last 2 years. On examination it was dense, mobile and nodular as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Most parotid and submandibular gland tumours grow slowly over a long period of time without causing symptoms.
  • A very small number cause discomfort by obstructing salivary ow.
  • Most benign tumours will be smooth, relatively mobile and painless to palpate.
  • The patient with a parotid tumour eventually becomes aware of a rm mass that is steadily getting bigger behind the angle of their jaw in the retromandibular region, in front of the tragus or in the cheek

Other options:

  • Dermoid cyst generally arise within the soft tissues from entrapped epithelium at lines of embryonic fusion. They are usually midline in location with most common location in the neck being submental triangle.
  • Sebaceous cysts are skin appendages lesions occurring mainly where there are sebaceous glands and are commonest in hairy skin, particularly in the beard region and scalp.

Reference: Scott brown 8th edition; Volume3; Page 116, 566, 613

questions.text: A woman is presented to ENT OPD with complaints of nasal obstruction O/E yellowish crusts are seen in nasal cavity covering turbinate & septum. She also had bad smell from nose with anosmia. What sign will you find in this case on anterior rhinoscopy examination
questions.solution:
This depicts the clinical scenario of Atrophic Rhinitis.

  • Anterior Rhinoscopy will show nasal cavity full of greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding. When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates.

Atrophic Rhinitis (OZAENA)

  • It is a chronic inflammation of nose characterized by atrophy of nasal mucosa and turbinate bones. The nasal cavities are roomy and full of foul-smelling crusts.
  • The exact cause is not known. Various theories have been proposed like hereditary, endocrine disturbances, racial factors, nutritional deficiencies (Vit. A, D & iron), infective and autoimmune process.
  • Disease is commonly seen in females and starts around puberty.
  • There is foul smell from the nose making the patient a social outcast though patient himself/herself is unaware of the smell due to marked anosmia (merciful anosmia)
  • Patient may complain of nasal obstruction in spite of unduly wide nasal chambers. This is due to large crusts filling the nose.
  • Examination shows nasal cavity to be full of greenish or greyish black dry crusts covering the turbinates and septum. Attempts to remove them may cause bleeding.
  • When the crusts have been removed, nasal cavities appear roomy with atrophy of turbinates
  • The disease persists for years but there is a tendency to recover spontaneously in middle age.
  • Treatment may be medical or surgical.
  • Medical management includes: nasal irrigation and removal of crusts; 25% glucose in glycerine; Kemicetione ozaena solution (chlormycetin, oestradiol and Vit D2); oestradiol spray, placental extracts, systemic streptomycin.
  • Surgical management: Young's operation or Modified Young's operation (promotes mucosa to revert back to normal and reduced crusting)
  • Nasal polyps cause nasal obstruction and nasal discharge but crusting and bad smell from nose are very rare features
  • Foreign body usually occurs in pediatric population, with history of purulent discharge or bleeding from nose
  • Inferior turbinate: Compensatory hypertrophy of the inferior turbinate is seen when the nasal septum is deviated to the opposite side, and the turbinate seems to fill the empty space. Hyperplasia of the turbinate head and whole length of the turbinate may both occur with chronic rhinitis. Should the head enlarge, the turbinate may enlarge anteriorly and obstruct the nasal valve. Hyperplasia of the posterior end is said to occur in patients with chronic sinusitis and post-nasal discharge.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 172-73

Reference: Scott brown 8th edition; Volume1; Page 1159

questions.text: Partial closure of nasal orifice is done in which condition?
questions.solution:
• Surgical management of atrophic rhinitis includes:
    1. Young's operation. Both the nostrils are closed completely just within the nasal vestibule by raising flaps. They are opened after 6 months or later. In these cases, mucosa may revert to normal and crusting reduced.
    2. Modified Young's operation. To avoid the discomfort of bilateral nasal obstruction, modified Young's operation aims to partially close the nostrils. It is also claimed to give the same benefit as Young's operation.
  • Other measures include narrowing the nasal cavities as nasal chambers are very wide in atrophic rhinitis and air currents dry up secretions leading to crusting. Narrowing the size of the nasal airway helps to relieve the symptoms. Among the techniques followed, some are:
    1. Submucosal injection of teflon paste.
    2. Insertion of fat, cartilage, bone or teflon strips under the mucoperiosteum of the floor and lateral wall of nose and the mucoperichondrium of the septum.
    3. Section and medial displacement of lateral wall of nose.

Other options:

  • Rhinoscleroma: Both streptomycin (1 g/day) and tetracycline (2 g/day) are given together for a minimum period of 4-6 weeks and repeated, if necessary, after 1 month. Treatment is stopped only when two consecutive cultures from the biopsy material are negative. Steroids can be combined to reduce fibrosis. Surgical treatment may be required to establish the airway and correct nasal deformity.
  • Vasomotor rhinitis: Treatment is mainly medical with avoidance of physical factors; antihistaminics and oral nasal decongestants and topical steroids. Surgical management is done to relieve nasal obstruction by reducing the size of nasal turbinates. Excessive rhinorrhoea, not corrected by medical therapy and bothersome to the patient, can be relieved by sectioning the parasympathetic secretomotor fibres to nose (vidian neurectomy).

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 173, 175, 191

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, muffled voice and difficulty in swallowing. The oropharyngeal picture is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image in the question depicts peritonsillar abscess (Quinsy).

Peritonsillar abscess (Quinsy)

  • It is a collection of pus in the peritonsillar space which lies between the capsule of tonsil and the superior constrictor muscle.
  • Peritonsillar abscess usually follows acute tonsillitis though it may arise de novo without previous history of sore throats. First, one of the tonsillar crypts, usually the crypta magna, gets infected and sealed off. It forms an intratonsillar abscess which then bursts through the tonsillar capsule to set up peritonsillitis and then an abscess.
  • Culture of pus from the abscess may reveal pure growth of Streptococcus pyogenes, S. aureus or anaerobic organisms. More often the growth is mixed, with both aerobic and anaerobic organisms.
  • It mostly affects adults and rarely the children though acute tonsillitis is more common in children.
  • Clinical features: include high grade fever (upto 104°F), severe pain in throat, odynophagia (so marked that the patient cannot even swallow his own saliva which dribbles from the angle of his mouth). Patient is usually dehydrated.
  • Patient has a muffled and thick speech, often called "hot potato voice" and foul breath due to sepsis in the oral cavity and poor hygiene.
  • Ipsilateral earache (referred pain via CN IX) and trismus (due to spasm of pterygoid muscles which are in close proximity to the superior constrictor)
  • Examination (as shown in the image) reveals: the tonsil, pillars and soft palate on the involved side are congested and swollen.
  • Tonsil itself may not appear enlarged as it gets buried in the oedematous pillar.
  • Uvula is swollen and oedematous and pushed to the opposite side.
  • Bulging of the soft palate and anterior pillar above the tonsil.
  • Mucopus may be seen covering the tonsillar region.
  • Cervical lymphadenopathy (jugulodigastric lymph nodes) is commonly seen.
  • Torticollis - Patient keeps the neck tilted to the side of abscess.
  • Treatment includes: Hospitalization, IVFs (to combat dehydration), antibiotics and analgesics.
  • If a frank abscess has formed, incision and drainage will be required. It is opened at the point of maximum bulge above the upper pole of tonsil or just lateral to the point of junction of anterior pillar with a line drawn through the base of uvula. With the help of a guarded knife, a small stab incision is made and then a sinus forceps inserted to open the abscess.
  • Surgical management include Interval tonsillectomy where tonsils are removed 4-6 weeks following an attack of quinsy.

Other options:

  • Parapharyngeal abscess: Anterior compartment involvement will present with prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa, trismus (due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle) and external swelling behind the angle of jaw. Posterior compartment involvement produces bulge of pharynx behind the posterior pillar, paralysis of CN IX, X, XI, and XII and sympathetic chain, and swelling of parotid region.
  • Retropharyngeal abscess: usually causes bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall with symptoms of dysphagia and torticollis.
  • Ludwig's angina: presents with trismus. When infection is localized to the sublingual space, structures in the floor of mouth are swollen and tongue seems to be pushed up and back. When infection spreads to submaxillary space, submental and submandibular regions become swollen and tender, and impart woody-hard feel. Usually, there is cellulitis of the tissues rather than frank abscess. Tongue is progressively pushed upwards and backwards threatening the airway. Laryngeal oedema may appear.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 298-99, 303.

questions.text: A 7 year old child while playing fell down. He has developed nasal blockage on both sides and there is swelling around the nose. What is the further treatment of this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario depicts formation of septal hematoma following trauma and I&D with antibiotics are the treatment of choice.

Septal Hematoma

  • It is collection of blood under the perichondrium or periosteum of the nasal septum. It often results from nasal trauma or septal surgery. In bleeding disorders, it may occur spontaneously.
  • Bilateral nasal obstruction is the commonest presenting symptom.
  • Examination reveals smooth rounded swelling of the septum in both the nasal fossae. Palpation may show the mass to be soft and fluctuant.
  • Small haematomas can be aspirated with a wide bore sterile needle. Larger haematomas are incised and drained by a small anteroposterior incision parallel to the nasal floor. Excision of a small piece of mucosa from the edge of incision gives better drainage.
  • Following drainage, nose is packed on both sides to prevent reaccumulation.
  • Systemic antibiotics should be given to prevent septal abscess.
  • Septal haematoma, if not drained, may organize into fibrous tissue leading to a permanently thickened septum.
  • If secondary infection supervenes, it results in septal abscess with necrosis of cartilage and depression of nasal dorsum.
  • Nasal bone fractures usually causes depression of nasal bridge with echymosis or nasal dorsal swelling due to soft tissue edema. Nasal obstruction is not the usual presentation.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 168

questions.text: A patient of total thyroidectomy was being extubated. the anaesthesiologist realized that when he removes the tube the patients being to have respiratory difficulty with stridor. Which of the following could be the most probable cause
questions.solution:
Stridor following total thyroidectomy occurs mostly due to Bilateral RLN palsy and mandates an emergency tracheostomy

  • Surgical trauma (thyroidectomy) is the most important cause of bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
  • As all the intrinsic muscles of larynx are paralyzed, the vocal cords lie in median or paramedian position due to unopposed action of cricothyroid muscles
  • The airway is inadequate causing dyspnoea and stridor but the voice is good
  • Many cases of bilateral abductor paralysis require tracheostomy as an emergency procedure or when they develop upper respiratory tract infection
  • In long-standing cases, the choice is between a permanent tracheostomy with a speaking valve or a surgical procedure to lateralize the cord.
  • Surgical procedures include:
  • Transverse cordotomy (Kashima operation)
  • Partial arytenoidectomy where medial part of arytenoid is excised with laser
  • Reinnervation procedures
  • Thyroplasty type II

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 338-39

choices.text: Start Intravenous line and Shift to Operation Theatre immediately
Adrenaline soaked packing in the Tonsillar fossa and observation in the ward

questions.text: A 7 year old post tonsillectomy child was lying in the ward. He started severely bleeding in the ward and is Which of the following should be done
questions.solution:
Post-tonsillectomy child with profuse oral bleeding needs to be urgently re-explored in main OT with ligation of bleeding vessels.

  • M/C cause of torrential bleeding during tonsillectomy: Tonsillar branch of facial artery (called as artery of tonsillar haemorrhage)
  • So, IV line assess is maintained, IVFs are given.
  • Patient is urgently shifted to OT for re-exploration and ligation of bleeding vessels
  • Hemorrhage following tonsillectomy till within 24 hours is called reactionary hemorrhage and requires re-exploration.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume2; Page 288

questions.text: A 10 year old child was brought by a mother with a history of dysphagia. On inquiry she informed that the child was playing alone & gave a history of foreign body ingestion. X-ray was done & images are given. What procedure would be needed in this patient?
questions.solution:
The X-ray lateral neck image in the question shows a foreign body in the esophagus and esophagoscopy is warranted to remove it.

Foreign body in esophagus

  • Usual foreign bodies that get lodged in the oesophagus are a coin, piece of meat, chicken bone, denture, safety pin or a marble. Sometimes other object like nails, screws, plastic objects or pieces of glass may also be seen. Disc batteries are also becoming common these days due to their wide spread usage.
  • Most of oesophageal foreign bodies lodge just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter.
  • Clinical symptoms mainly include throat pain or substernal pain (which increases on attempts to swallow), dysphagia, drooling of swallow (in case of complete obstruction)
  • Pooling of secretions in the pyriform fossa on indirect laryngoscopy
  • Radiology (Xray):
    • Foreign bodies of the oesophagus lie in the coronal plane in PA view and edge on in the lateral view. It is just the reverse in tracheal foreign bodies because of orientation of vocal cords.
    • Radiolucent foreign bodies may show as an air bubble in cervical oesophagus in X-ray soft tissue lateral view of neck.
  • Most of the foreign bodies in oesophagus can be removed by oesophagoscopy under general anaesthesia. Both rigid and flexible scopes have been used to remove foreign bodies from the oesophagus.

Other options:

  • Heimlich manoeuvre: This is done for laryngeal foreign body when a large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken. Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway. Cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be done if Heimlich manoeuvre fails. Once acute respiratory emergency is over, foreign body can be removed by direct laryngoscopy or by laryngofissure, if impacted.
  • Bronchoscopy and tracheostomy will not help here since this is a esophageal foreign body.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 395-96, 367

questions.text: A 60 year old patient with a nasal lesion as shown in the image, choose the most appropriate diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Basal cell carcinoma (rodent ulcer)

  • This is the most common malignant tumour involving skin of nose (87%), equally affecting males and females in the age group of 40-60 years
  • Common sites on the nose are the tip and the ala, however can occur anywhere in head and neck region on sun-exposed area
  • It may present as a cyst or papulo-pearly nodule or an ulcer with rolled edges.
  • It is very slow growing and remains confined to the skin for a long time. Underlying cartilage or bone may get invaded.
  • Nodal metastases are extremely rare.
  • Histological subtypes include nodular, superficial, basosquamous, pigmented and morpheic (nodular BCC being the most common)
  • Treatment depends on the size, location and depth of the tumour.
  • Early lesion can be cured by cryosurgery, irradiation or surgical excision with 3-5 mm of healthy skin around the palpable borders of the tumour.
  • Nodular and morphoeic BCCs are best treated with surgical excision. Small, well-defined lesions may be excised with peripheral margins of 4-5 mm and deep margins down to fat. This method has a clearance rate of approximately 95%. The adequacy of excision is judged by histological clearance of at least 1 mm at both the peripheral and deep margins.
  • Infiltrative, morpheic or large BCCs will need wider margins to achieve the same success rate.
  • Lesions which are recurrent, extensive or with involvement of cartilage or bone are excised with adequate margins and the surgical defect closed by local or distant flaps or a prosthesis.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page163

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume3; Page 1325

questions.text: Identify the X-Ray view given in the image?
questions.solution:
The image shows Caldwell view

  • Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position). The view is taken with nose and forehead touching the film and X-ray beam is projected 15-20° caudally.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Frontal sinuses (seen best)
    2. Ethmoid sinuses
    3. Maxillary sinuses
    4. Frontal process of zygoma and zygomatic process of frontal bone
    5. Superior margin of orbit and lamina papyracea
    6. Superior orbital fissure
    7. Foramen rotundum (inferolateral to superior orbitalfissure)

Other options:

Schuller's View

  • It is lateral oblique view of mastoid.
  • Patient lies in such a way that sagittal plane of the skull is parallel to the film and X-ray beam is projected 30° cephalocaudal
  • Structures seen are:
    1. External canal superimposed on internal canal
    2. Mastoid air cells
    3. Tegmen
    4. Lateral sinus plate
    5. Condyle of mandible
    6. Sinodural angle
    7. Antrum and upper part of attic (i.e. key area)
  • This view is taken to see the extent of pneumatization, destruction of intercellular septa (as in mastoiditis), location of sinus plate and tegmen, cholesteatoma and longitudinal fracture of petrous pyramid.

Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position). It is taken in such a way that nose and chin of the patient touch the film while X-ray beam is projected from behind. Water's view with open mouth is preferred as it also shows sphenoid sinus. In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.

  • Structures seen are:
    1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best).
    2. Frontal sinuses.
    3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth).
    4. Zygoma.
    5. Zygomatic arch.
    6. Nasal bone.
    7. Frontal process of maxilla.
    8. Superior orbital fissure.
    9. Intratemporal fossa.

Towne's view: It is anteroposterior view with 30° tilt from above and in front. It shows both petrous pyramids which can be compared.

  • Structures seen are:
    1. Arcuate eminence and superior semicircular canal.
    2. Mastoid antrum.
    3. Internal auditory canal.
    4. Tympanic cavity.
    5. Cochlea.
    6. External auditory canal.
  • This view is usually taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 493-94

questions.text: The given two nasal features are seen in patient of epistaxis and external nasal deformity. Biopsy from the nose has revealed the necrotizing vasculitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
WEGENER’S GRANULOMATOSIS

  • It is a systemic disorder of unknown aetiology involving mainly the upper airways, lungs, kidneys and the skin.
  • Early symptoms of Wegener's granulomatosis include clear or blood-stained nasal discharge which later becomes purulent. The patient often complains of persistent cold.
  • Nasal findings include crusting, granulations, septal perforation and a saddle nose
  • Destruction may also involve eyes, orbit, palate, oral cavity or oropharynx. Middle ear can also be involved.
  • General systemic symptoms include anaemia, fatigue, night sweats and migratory arthralgias.
  • Involvement of lung is manifested by cough and sometimes haemoptysis. X-ray chest may show a single or multiple cavity lesions.
  • Sooner or later, kidneys are also involved. Urine examination will show red cells, casts and albumin. Serum creatinine level is raised. Renal failure is the usual cause of death in these patients.
  • Biopsy from the nose is diagnostic. It shows necrosis and ulceration of mucosa, epithelioid granuloma and necrotizing vasculitis involving small arteries or veins.
  • Erythrocyte sedimentation rate is raised.
  • Treatment consists of systemic steroids and cytotoxic drugs.
  • Cyclophosphamide and azathioprine, both are found effective.

Other options:

  • Saddle Nose may involve bony, cartilaginous or both bony and cartilaginous components of nasal dorsum and is sometimes caused by leprosy, tuberculosis or syphilis.
  • Tertiary syphilis: This is the stage in which nose is commonly involved. Typical manifestation is the formation of a gumma on the nasal septum. Later, the septum is destroyed both in its bony and cartilaginous parts. Perforation may also appear in the hard palate. There is offensive nasal discharge with crusts. Bony or cartilaginous sequestra may be seen. Bridge of the nose collapses causing a saddle nose deformity.
  • Tuberculosis: A granulomatous disease where anterior part of nasal septum and anterior end of inferior turbinate are the sites commonly involved. First, there is nodular infiltration followed later by ulceration and perforation of nasal septum in its cartilaginous part.
  • Leprosy: Infection starts in the anterior part of nasal septum and anterior end of inferior turbinate. Initially, there is excessive nasal discharge with red and swollen mucosa. Later, crusting and bleeding supervene. Nodular lesions on the septum may ulcerate and cause perforation. Late sequelae of disease are atrophic rhinitis, depression of bridge of nose and destruction of anterior nasal spine with retrusion of the columella

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 175-79

questions.text: A COVID 19 patient on high dose of methylprednisolone has presented to ENT OPD with blood stained nasal discharge and progressive blackish nasal discoloration. Which of the following is the choice of therapy?
questions.solution:
COVID19 patient on high dose steroids (immunosupression effect) with blood stained nasal discharge and progressive blackish nasal discoloration points to the diagnosis of Mucormycosis. Liposomal amphotericin B is the drug of choice for mucormycosis.

MUCORMYCOSIS

  • It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal.
  • It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.
  • From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain.
  • CECT PNS with orbit or MRI PNS with orbit is done to delineate the extent of disease and tissue destruction and necrosis.
  • MRI Brain is done to detect intracranial extension
  • The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.
  • Typical finding is the presence of a black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.
  • Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.
  • Treatment is by liposomal amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 178

questions.text: Which anatomical level is being shown by the arrow in given X-ray Cervical Spine, Lateral view
questions.solution:
The arrow in the image shows the level of C4-C5 vertebra which corresponds to the level of upper border of the thyroid cartilage.

  • The cricoid cartilage is a ring-shaped laryngeal cartilage that sits below the thyroid cartilage and above the tracheal rings, at the level of the C6 vertebra. It is the only complete cartilaginous ring of the whole airway.
  • Hyoid bone corresponds to the level of C4 vertebra.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume3; Page 885-6

choices.text: Humidified oxygen with antibiotic and steroid

questions.text: A patient presented in emergency department with c/o respiratory distress and cough. Steeple sign was found on X-ray. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Respiratory distress with cough and steeple sign on x-ray points to the diagnosis of Croup (Acute Laryngotracheobronchitis). Hospitalisation, i.v antibiotics with steroids and humidified oxygen are the treatment of choice. Intubation might be required in case of severe distress.

ACUTE LARYNGO-TRACHEO-BRONCHITIS

  • It is an inflammatory condition of the larynx, trachea and bronchi; more common than acute epiglottitis.
  • Mostly, it is viral infection (parainfluenza type I and II) affecting children between 6 months and 3 years of age.
  • Male children are more often affected.
  • Secondary bacterial infection by Gram-positive cocci soon supervenes.
  • Pathology: The loose areolar tissue in the subglottic region swells up and causes respiratory obstruction and stridor. This, coupled with thick tenacious secretions and crusts, may completely occlude the airway.
  • Disease starts as upper respiratory infection with hoarseness and croupy cough. with fever of 39-40°C.
  • This may be followed by difficulty in breathing and inspiratory type of stridor. Respiratory difficulty may gradually increase with signs of upper airway obstruction, i.e. suprasternal and intercostal recession.
  • Treatment includes:
    1. Hospitalisation is often essential because of the increasing difficulty in breathing. Any manipulation of the patient can precipitate acute respiratory distress.
      • Administer inhalation anaesthesia (sevoflurane) and humidified oxygen to the patient, secure i.v. line and then perform laryngoscopy to make the diagnosis.
      • Take laryngeal swabs for culture and sensitivity tests and intubate the patient.
      • Most of the patients recover with antibiotics, steroids and intubation within 48 h.
    2. Antibiotics like ampicillin 50 mg/kg/day in divided doses are effective against secondary infections due to Gram-positive cocci and H. influenzae.
    3. Humidification helps to soften crusts and tenacious secretions which block tracheobronchial tree.
    4. Parenteral fluids are essential to combat dehydration.
    5. Steroids, e.g. hydrocortisone 100 mg i.v. may be useful to relieve oedema.
    6. Adrenaline, racemic adrenaline administered via a respirator is a bronchodilator and may relieve dyspnoea and avert tracheostomy.
    7. Intubation/tracheostomy is done, should respiratory obstruction increase inspite of above measures.
  • Tracheostomy is done if intubation is required beyond 72 hours. Assisted ventilation may be required.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 328

questions.text: A 7 year old child comes to you with complaints of snoring, mouth breathing with hearing loss. His school performance is deteriorating. What is the next line of management for the child?
questions.solution:
Child with complaints suggestive of nasal obstruction and hearing loss leading to deteriorating school performance should clinch the diagnosis of adenoid hypertrophy. For symptomatic cases with SOM should be treated with adenoidectomy and grommet insertion.

  • The nasopharyngeal tonsil, commonly called "adenoids", is situated at the junction of the roof and posterior wall of the nasopharynx.
  • Adenoid tissue is present at birth, shows physiological enlargement up to the age of 6 years, and then tends to atrophy at puberty and almost completely disappears by the age of 20
  • Nasal obstruction is the commonest symptom of adenoid hypertrophy. This leads to mouth breathing. Nasal obstruction also interferes with feeding or suckling in a child. As respiration and feeding cannot take place simultaneously, a child with adenoid enlargement fails to thrive as in this case with severe adenoid hypertrophy.
  • Nasal discharge, sinusitits and epistaxis can also occur
  • Voice is toneless and loses nasal quality due to nasal obstruction, condition known as rhinolalaia clausa.
  • Recurrent attacks of AOM; CSOM and OME are aural features.
  • Child will have characteristic facial features called adenoid facies
  • Aprosexia, i.e. lack of concentration; school performance may deteriorate.
  • Long-standing nasal obstruction due to adenoid hypertrophy can cause pulmonary hypertension and cor pulmonale.
  • When symptoms are not marked, breathing exercises, decongestant nasal drops and antihistaminics for any co-existent nasal allergy can cure the condition without resort to surgery.
  • When symptoms are marked, adenoidectomy is done. Grommet insertion should be done for SOM in the same sitting.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 275-76

choices.text: Tear to posterior wall of trachea

questions.text: After emergency tracheostomy patient presented with surgical emphysema. What is the most likely reason?
questions.solution:
If the tracheostomy wound is closed too tightly around the tube, or the dressings are too tightly applied to the neck skin, air may leak into the soft tissues of the neck leading to surgical emphysema.

Pneumothorax, Pneumomediastinum & Surgical emphysema

  • Inadvertently straying from the midline during dissection increases the risk of post-operative pneumothorax.
  • This should be detected immediately post-operatively on a routine chest X-ray.
  • Small pneumothoraces can be treated conservatively while larger ones will require chest drainage.
  • If the tracheostomy wound is closed too tightly around the tube, or the dressings are too tightly applied to the neck skin, air may leak into the soft tissues of the neck (surgical emphysema) or track down into the mediastinum.
  • In this instance the wound should be reopened to allow air to track back out through the tissues and a corrugated drain should be inserted.
  • Pneumothorax is a rare complication in elective tracheostomy but common in emergency tracheostomy.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume2; Page 405

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of bleeding from nose, nasal obstruction, and difficulty in breathing. He gave the history of bathing in the local pool near his house. On examination, red nasal studded surface mass with whitish dots on the surface is observed. Based on the history, examination and given histopathological image, what will be the diagnosis of the patient?
questions.solution:
RHINOSPORIDIOSIS

  • It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and affects both man and animals.
  • In India, disease is more common in the southern states. It is prevalent in the states of Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Puducherry and Andhra Pradesh.
  • It has long been considered to be a fungus but it has been difficult to classify this organism. It has not been cultured so far. However, some consider it to be a protozoan or a fish parasite belonging to the DRIP clade (Dermocystidium, Rosette agent, Ichthyophonus and Psorospermum).
  • The disease mostly affects nose and nasopharynx; other sites such as lip, palate, conjunctiva, epiglottis, larynx, trachea, bronchi, skin, vulva and vagina may also be affected.
  • The disease is acquired through contaminated water of ponds also frequented by animals.
  • Nasal endoscopy: The disease presents as a leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in colour and attached to nasal septum or lateral wall.
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate.
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch.
    • Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia.
  • In early stages, the patient may complain of nasal discharge which is often blood tinged and nasal stuffiness.
  • Sometimes, frank epistaxis is the only presenting complaint.
  • Diagnosis is made on biopsy. It shows several sporangia, oval or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.
  • Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base.
  • Recurrence may occur after surgical excision.
  • Not many drugs are effective against the disease. Dapsone has been tried with some success.

Other options:

  • Rhinoscleroma: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Gramnegative bacillus called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis or Frisch bacillus. The disease runs through the following stages: Atrophic, granulomatous and cicatricial stage. Granulomatous nodules form in nasal mucosa. There is also subdermal infiltration of lower part of external nose and upper lip giving a "woody" feel.
  • Rhinophyma is due to hypertrophy of sebaceous glands of the nasal tip. It is associated with acne rosacea.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 175, 177-8, 510

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic male patient was admitted with a diagnosis of Covid-19 Based on positive RT-PCR. Due to severe lung involvement he was treated with methylprednisolone. The patient was re-admitted to hospital, due to nasal obstruction and left side facial and orbital swelling, several days after discharge. In sinus endoscopic surgery, debridement was performed and the specimens were sent to pathology. A nasal biopsy showed wide hyphae without septa as shown in the given slide. Choose the most appropriate diagnosis
questions.solution:
COVID19 patient treated with methylprednisolone presenting with nasal obstruction and left side facial and orbital swelling points to the diagnosis of Mucormycosis.

MUCORMYCOSIS

  • It is fungal infection of nose and paranasal sinuses which may prove rapidly fatal.
  • It is seen in uncontrolled diabetics or in those taking immunosuppressive drugs.
  • From the nose and sinuses, infection can spread to orbit, cribriform plate, meninges and brain.
  • CECT PNS with orbit or MRI PNS with orbit is done to delineate the extent of disease and tissue destruction and necrosis.
  • MRI Brain is done to detect intracranial extension
  • The rapid destruction associated with the disease is due to affinity of the fungus to invade the arteries and cause endothelial damage and thrombosis.
  • Typical finding is the presence of a black necrotic mass filling the nasal cavity and eroding the septum and hard palate.
  • Special stains help to identify the fungus in tissue sections.
  • The Mucorales are characterized by anamorph structures. The mycelium is typically non-septate (coenocytic) or irregularly septate. Sporangiospores are produced in multi-sporangia. The sporangia are characterized by the inclusion of a variously shaped columella.
  • Treatment is by liposomal amphotericin B and surgical debridement of the affected tissues and control of underlying predisposing cause.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 178

questions.text: A child has swallowed a foreign body. What is the nature of foreign body as per X-Ray
questions.solution:
This is an Chest x-ray AP view showing disc battery in esophagus with double ring sign.

  • Halo sign (double ring sign) in AP view and step-off sign in the lateral view of the x-ray are pathognomonic for button battery ingestion compared to a coin.
  • Ingestion of disc batteries is becoming common because of their widespread use in hearing aids, toys, calculators and other electronic devices.
  • They contain sodium hydroxide, potassium hydroxide and mercury which leaks through them to cause oesophageal injury. Prolonged sojourn at one place causes complications like stricture, perforation, tracheo-oesophageal fistula, mediastinitis and death.
  • A disc battery causes damage to mucosa in 1 h, muscle coat in 2-4 h and perforation of the oesophagus in 8-12 h, therefore it should be removed promptly from the oesophagus.
  • If lodged in stomach, a radiographic follow up is conducted every 4-7 days and parents instructed to observe stools daily for spontaneous passage.
  • If patient is a child under 6 years and battery size is 1.5 cm or more, follow-up X-ray examination is done after 48 h of ingestion and if the battery is still in stomach, it is removed endoscopically.

Reference: Radiopedia.org; Esophageal foreign body button battery ingestion

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 177-8

questions.text: Which sensory nerve supplies the larynx above the vocal cord?
questions.solution:
Sensory supply of Larynx:

  • Above the vocal cords, larynx is supplied by internal laryngeal nerve-a branch of superior laryngeal nerve
  • Below the vocal cords-by recurrent laryngeal nerve.

Motor supplyof Larynx:

  • All the muscles which move the vocal cord (abductors, adductors or tensors) are supplied by the recurrent laryngeal nerve except the cricothyroid which receives its innervation from the external laryngeal nerve-a branch of superior laryngeal nerve.

Extra edge:

  • Recurrent laryngeal nerve: Right recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the vagus at the level of subclavian artery, hooks around it, and then ascends between the trachea and oesophagus. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve arises from the vagus in the mediastinum at the level ofarch of aorta, loops around it, and then ascends into the neck in the tracheo-oesophageal groove. Thus, left recurrent laryngeal nerve has a much longer course which makes it more prone to paralysis compared to the right one.
  • Superior laryngeal nerve: It arises from inferior ganglion of the vagus, descends behind internal carotid artery and, at the level of greater cornua of hyoid bone, divides into external and internal branches. The external branch supplies cricothyroid muscle while the internal branch pierces the thyrohyoid membrane and supplies sensory innervation to the larynx and hypopharynx.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 337

choices.text: Both vocal cords involved and fixed
Both vocal cords involved and mobile
One vocal cord involved and fixed
One vocal cord involved and mobile

questions.text: Which of the following best describes Laryngeal cancer stage T1bN0M0
questions.solution: Reference: Stell Maran Textbook of head and neck surgery and oncology; 5th edition; Page 646

questions.text: The patient presents with complaints of reddish nasal mass, unilateral nasal obstruction associated with w nasal bleeding and the diagnosis of inverted papilloma is made. Which is true regarding the following condition?
questions.solution:
Inverted Papilloma (Transitional Cell Papilloma or Ringertz Tumour or Schneiderian Papilloma)

  • It is a tumour of the nonolfactory mucosa of nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.
  • Though benign, these lesions are locally invasive & commonly recur and are associated with squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Most common site of origin is lateral wall of nose in the middle meatus; less commonly it arises from the maxillary, frontal or sphenoid sinus
  • It is so named because hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma rather than in exophytic manner
  • Human papilloma virus is thought to be responsible for its aetiology.
  • Clinically, men are affected more than women in the age group of 40-70.
  • It is almost always unilateral and presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge and epistaxis.
  • It can invade sinuses or orbit. Orbital involvement causes proptosis, diplopia and lacrimation.
  • On nasal endoscopy, it presents as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polypus or polypi
  • Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion.
  • CT features include internal calcification, and bony erosion or bowing. Focal hyperostosis is a finding which has been said to correlate with the site of origin of this neoplasm - a finding which has potential relevance in planning the extent of surgery needed to achieve extirpation.
  • On MRI a characteristic convoluted, cerebrifrom pattern is said to be highly suggestive of this diagnosis, with the concomitant finding of necrosis suggesting a coexistent focus of carcinoma
  • MRI also helps to differentiate associated secretions in sinus from the actual tumour mass.
  • Biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
  • Care should be taken as simple nasal polypi may be associated with it or even the patient might have been operated for their removal.
  • Treatment: Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. It can be performed by lateral rhinotomy or sublabial degloving approach. These days endoscopic approach is preferred.
  • In 10-15% of cases, it is associated with malignancy.
  • Wider external surgical approaches may be required for tumour extending to the frontal sinus or orbit.
  • Recurrence can occur.
  • Radiotherapy is not advised as it may induce malignancy.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 227

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume1; Page 311

questions.text: Identify the structure marked with arrow in the given X-ray image of paranasal sinuses
questions.solution:
X-ray shows above is X-ray Paranasal Sinuses (Water's view)

Water's view(Occipitomental view or nose-chin position)

  • It is taken in such a way that nose and chin of the patient touch the film while X-ray beam is projected from behind.
  • Water's view with open mouth is preferred as it also shows sphenoid sinus. In this view, petrous bones are projected below the maxillary antra.
  • Structures seen are:
    1. Maxillary sinuses (seen best)
    2. Frontal sinuses
    3. Sphenoid sinus (if the film is taken with open mouth)
    4. Zygoma
    5. Zygomatic arch
    6. Nasal bone
    7. Frontal process of maxilla
    8. Superior orbital fissure
    9. Intratemporal fossa

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 493

questions.text: An infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of noisy breathing. The stridor was reported to improve on lying prone. The image of the airway is given below. What type of stridor is expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
The image shown is a typical laryngoscopic picture of laryngomalacia.

Laryngomalacia

  • Laryngomalacia is characterized by partial or complete collapse of the supraglottic structures on inspiration and is the most common congenital cause of stridor
  • Flexible Laryngoscopy: The aryepiglottic folds are short and tightly tethered to the epiglottis; there may also be redundant mucosa and submucosa of the aryepiglottic folds medially. The result is a tall, narrow supraglottis with a deep interarytenoid cleft where the epiglottis is soft and may curl and collapse and the mucosa may prolapse into the airway.
  • The stridor is high-pitched, fluttering, inspiratory and is usually present at, or shortly after, birth. Stridor is increased on crying but subsides on placing the child in prone position; cry is normal.
  • The severity of the stridor tends to increase as the child becomes more active during the first 9 months of life, and then gradually diminishes until by the age of 2 years it has generally disappeared. Very rarely, stridor may persist into late childhood.
  • Treatment is mostly conservative. Surgery may be required for severe cases.
  • Tracheostomy may be required for some cases of severe respiratory obstruction.
  • Supraglottoplasty is required in cases of severe laryngomalacia.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume 2; Pediatrics Section - Page 333

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat & Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 333

questions.text: Bulla ethmoidalis is anatomically located in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Bulla Ethmoidalis

  • Bulla ethmoidalis is anatomically located in middle meatus
  • It is an ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process
  • Anterior surface of the bulla forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris.
  • Depending on pneumatization, bulla may be a pneumatized cell or a solid bony prominence.
  • It may extend superiorly to the skull base and posteriorly to fuse with ground lamella.
  • When there is a space above or behind the bulla, it is called suprabullar or retrobullar recesses, respectively.
  • The suprabullar and retrobullar recesses together form the lateral sinus (sinus lateralis of Grunwald).
  • The lateral sinus is thus bounded superiorly by the skull base, laterally by lamina papyracea, medially by middle turbinate and inferiorly by the bulla ethmoidalis. Posteriorly, the sinus lateralis may extend up to basal lamella of middle turbinate.
  • The cleft-like communication between the bulla and skull base and opening into middle meatus is also called hiatus semilunaris superior.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 151

choices.text: Put the baby in prone position

questions.text: A newborn baby is having cyanotic spell at birth with difficulty in breathing. The symptoms improve with crying. What is urgent priority in the management of the given condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario mentioned gives the diagnosis of bilateral choanal atresia which needs emergency management

CHOANAL ATRESIA

  • It is due to persistence of bucconasal membrane and may be unilateral or bilateral, complete or incomplete, bony (90%) or membranous (10%).
  • Unilateral atresia is more common and may remain undiagnosed until adult life.
  • Bilateral atresia presents with respiratory obstruction as the newborn, being a natural nose breather, does not breathe from mouth.
  • Diagnosis of choanal atresia can be made by:
    1. presence of mucoid discharge in the nose
    2. absence of air bubbles in the nasal discharge
    3. failure to pass a catheter from nose to pharynx
    4. putting a few drops of a dye (methylene blue) into the nose and seeing its passage into the pharynx,
    5. flexible nasal endoscopy
    6. installing radioopaque dye into the nose and taking a lateral film, and
    7. computed tomography (CT) scan in axial plane is more useful.
  • Emergency management may be required in bilateral choanal atresia to provide an airway.
  • A feeding nipple with a large hole provides a good oral airway (McGovern's technique) and obviates the need for tracheostomy
  • Definitive treatment consists of correction of atresia by transnasal or transpalatal approach. The latter is usually done at one and a half years.
  • Choanal atresia can be corrected by using nasal endoscopes and drill including a part of posterior nasal septum transnasally.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 183

questions.text: A child is brought to the OPD with sudden bout of cough & breathlessness. There is no significant history given by the parents. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bronchial foreign body:

  • Symptoms and signs include Cough, wheeze and diminished air entry to lung forms a "triad"
  • Respiratory distress with swelling of foreign body
  • Lung collapse, emphysema, pneumonitis, bronchiectasis or lung abscess are late features
  • Most foreign bodies enter the right bronchus because it is wider and more in line with the tracheal lumen.
  • A foreign body may totally obstruct a lobar or segmental bronchus causing atelectasis or it may produce a check valve obstruction, allowing only ingress of air but, not the egress, thus leading to obstructive emphysema.

Other options:

Foreign body in esophagus

  • Most of oesophageal foreign bodies lodge just below the cricopharyngeal sphincter. Clinical symptoms mainly include throat pain or substernal pain (which increases on attempts to swallow), dysphagia, drooling of swallow (in case of complete obstruction)
  • Pooling of secretions in the pyriform fossa on indirect laryngoscopy
  • Radiology (Xray):
    • Foreign bodies of the oesophagus lie in the coronal plane in PA view and edge on in the lateral view. It is just the reverse in tracheal foreign bodies because of orientation of vocal cords.
    • Radiolucent foreign bodies may show as an air bubble in cervical oesophagus in X-ray soft tissue lateral view of neck.
  • Most of the foreign bodies in oesophagus can be removed by oesophagoscopy under general anaesthesia. Both rigid and flexible scopes have been used to remove foreign bodies from the oesophagus.

Foreign body Larynx

  • Large foreign body may totally obstruct the airway leading to sudden death unless resuscitative measures are taken urgently. A partially obstructive foreign body will cause discomfort or pain in the throat, hoarseness of voice, croupycough, aphonia, dyspnoea, wheezing and haemoptysis.
  • Heimlich manoeuvre: This is done for laryngeal foreign body when a large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway. Cricothyrotomy or emergency tracheostomy should be done if Heimlich manoeuvre fails. Once acute respiratory emergency is over, foreign body can be removed by direct laryngoscopy or by laryngofissure, if impacted.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 365, 395

questions.text: A 54 year old male presented with nasal obstruction. On examination there is a polypoidal mass in the posterior part of nasal cavity. This mass is better visible on posterior rhinoscopy. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANTROCHOANAL POLYP (SYN. KILLIAN'S POLYP)

  • This polyp arises from the mucosa of maxillary antrum near its accessory ostium, comes out of it and grows in the choana and nasal cavity.
  • Thus it has three parts.
    1. Antral, which is a thin stalk.
    2. Choanal, which is round and globular.
    3. Nasal, which is flat from side to side.
  • Exact cause is unknown. Nasal allergy coupled with sinus infection is incriminated.
  • Antrochoanal polypi are seen in children and young adults.
  • Usually they are single and unilateral.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction is the presenting symptom.
  • Obstruction may become bilateral when polyp grows into the nasopharynx and starts obstructing the opposite choana
  • Voice may become thick and dull due to hyponasality.
  • Nasal discharge, mostly mucoid, may be seen on one or both sides.
  • As the antrochoanal polyp grows posteriorly, it may be missed on anterior rhinoscopy.
  • When large, a smooth greyish mass covered with nasal discharge may be seen. It is soft and can be moved up and down with a probe.
  • A large polyp may protrude from the nostril and show a pink congested look on its exposed part.
  • Posterior rhinoscopy may reveal a globular mass filling the choana or the nasopharynx. A large polyp may hang down behind the soft palate and present in the oropharynx
  • X-rays of paranasal sinuses may show opacity of the involved antrum.
  • X-ray (lateral view), soft tissue nasopharynx, reveals a globular swelling in the postnasal space.
  • It is differentiated from angiofibroma by the presence of a column of air behind the polyp (Dodd sign)
  • Non-contrast CT scans and paranasal sinuses show the extent of the polyp.
  • The treatment of choice for antrochonal polyp is endoscopic sinus surgery.
  • An antrochoanal polyp is easily removed by avulsion either through the nasal or oral route.
  • Recurrence is uncommon after complete removal.

Other options:

  • Rhinoscleroma: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Gramnegative bacillus called Klebsiella rhinoscleromatis or Frisch bacillus. The disease runs through the following stages: atrophic, granulomatous and cicatricial stage. Granulomatous nodules form in nasal mucosa. There is also subdermal infiltration of lower part of external nose and upper lip giving a "woody" feel.
  • Rhinosporidiosis: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi and affects both man and animals. In India, disease is more common in the southern states of Tamil Nadu, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Chhattisgarh, Puducherry and Andhra Pradesh. The disease mostly affects nose and nasopharynx; other sites such as lip, palate, conjunctiva, epiglottis, larynx, trachea, bronchi, skin, vulva and vagina may also be affected.
    • The disease is acquired through contaminated water of ponds also frequented by animals.
    • Nasal endoscopy: a leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in colour and attached to nasal septum or lateral wall.
    • Sometimes, it extends into the nasopharynx and may hang behind the soft palate.
    • The mass is very vascular and bleeds easily on touch. Its surface is studded with white dots representing the sporangia.
    • In early stages, the patient may complain of nasal discharge which is often blood tinged and nasal stuffiness. Sometimes, frank epistaxis is the only presenting complaint.
    • Diagnosis is made on biopsy. It shows several sporangia, oval or round in shape and filled with spores which may be seen bursting through its chitinous wall.
    • Complete excision of the mass with diathermy knife and cauterization of its base.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 193, 175, 177

questions.text: A female presented with the following nose deformity, which of the following is unlikely a cause for it ?
questions.solution:
Saddle nose deformity can be caused by all choices except lupus vulgaris.

Saddle Nose

  • Depressed nasal dorsum may involve bony, cartilaginous or both bony and cartilaginous components of nasal dorsum
  • Nasal trauma causing depressed fractures is the most common aetiology.
  • It can also result from excessive removal of septum in submucous resection, destruction of septal cartilage by haematoma or abscess, sometimes by leprosy, tuberculosis or syphilis.
  • The deformity can be corrected by augmentation rhinoplasty by filling the dorsum with cartilage, bone or a synthetic implant.
  • If depression is only cartilaginous, cartilage is taken from the nasal septum or auricle and laid in a single or multiple layers.
  • If deformity involves both cartilage and bone, cancellous bone from the iliac crest is the best.
  • Autografts (taken from the same individual) are preferred to allografts (taken from other individuals or cadavers).
  • Saddle deformity can also be corrected by synthetic implants of silicone or teflon but they are likely to be extruded.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 161

questions.text: Name the anterior most ethmoidal cell marked in the figure
questions.solution:
• Agger nasi is the anterior-most ethmoid air cell. The degree of pneumatization of the agger nasi influences the position of the superior uncinate process and thickness of the bony nasofrontal beak.

Other options:

  • Bulla ethmoidalis (ethmoid bulla) is the largest and most consistent anterior air cell.
  • Pneumatization of middle turbinate leads to an enlarged ballooned out middle turbinate called concha bullosa. It drains into frontal recess directly or through agger nasi cells.
  • Roof of the ethmoid is formed by medial extension of the orbital plate of the frontal bone, which shows depressions on its undersurface, called fovea ethmoidalis. The lateral wall is formed by a thin plate of bone called lamina papyracea.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume1 ; Page 973

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 153, 209

questions.text: Name the structure marked in the figure :
questions.solution:
The arrows point towards pyriform fossa that lies on either side of larynx.

Pyriform sinus (fossa)

  • It lies on either side of the larynx and extends from pharyngoepiglottic fold to the upper end of oesophagus.
  • It is bounded laterally by the thyrohyoid membrane and the thyroid cartilage and medially by the aryepiglottic fold, posterolateral surfaces of arytenoid and cricoid cartilages
  • It forms the lateral channel for food.
  • Foreign bodies may lodge in the pyriform fossa.
  • Internal laryngeal nerve runs submucosally in the lateral wall of the sinus and thus is easily accessible for local anaesthesia. It is also through this nerve that pain is referred to the ear in carcinoma of the pyriform sinus.
  • Pyriform sinus is richly supplied by lymphatics which exit through the thyrohyoid membrane and drain into the upper jugular chain.

Other options:

  • Fossa of Rosenmuller: In lateral wall of nasopharynx, above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess called fossa of Rosenmuller, which is the commonest site for origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma
  • Saccule is a diverticulum of mucous membrane which starts from the anterior part of ventricular cavity and extends upwards between vestibular folds and lamina of thyroid cartilage. When abnormally enlarged and distended, it may form a laryngocele-an air containing sac which may present in the neck. There are many mucous glands in the saccule, which help to lubricate the vocal cords.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 272, 321

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the following Endoscopic image of Nasal cavity
questions.solution:
The arrow in the image points toward inferior turbinate

Inferior Turbinate

  • The middle and superior turbinates arise from extensions of the ethmoid bones whereas the inferior turbinate is an embryologically independent osseus structure.
  • The lacrimal duct drains into the inferior meatus approximately 1 cm posterior to the head of the inferior turbinate.
  • Although not considered a true valve, the opening of the nasolacrimal duct is called Hasner's valve which is formed by small folds of mucosa.

Reference: Scott Brown 8th edition; Volume1 ; Page 968

questions.text: Which of the following marked structures constitute parts of the Larynx
questions.solution:
Alphabetically marked structures are:

A. Epiglottis,

B. Hyoid bone,

C. Thyroid cartilage and

D. Cricoid cartilage.

All these except hyoid bone constitute parts of larynx.

  • Larynx has three unpaired and three paired cartilages
  • Unpaired: Thyroid, cricoid and epiglottis
  • Paired: Arytenoid, corniculate and cuneiform
  1. Thyroid: It is the largest of all. Its two alae meet anteriorly forming an angle of 90° in male and 120° in females. Vocal cords are attached to the middle of thyroid angle. Most of laryngeal foreign bodies are arrested above the vocal cords, i.e. above the middle of thyroid cartilage and an effective airway can be provided by piercing the cricothyroid membrane - a procedure called cricothyrotomy.
  2. Cricoid: It is the only cartilage forming a complete ring. Its posterior part is expanded to form a lamina while anteriorly it is narrow forming an arch.
  3. Epiglottis: It is a leaf-like, yellow, elastic cartilage forming anterior wall of laryngeal inlet. It is attached to the body of hyoid bone by hyoepiglottic ligament, which divides it into suprahyoid and infrahyoid epiglottis. A stalk-like process of epiglottis (petiole) attaches the epiglottis to the thyroid angle just above the attachment of vocal cords. Anterior surface of epiglottis is separatedfrom thyrohyoid membrane and upper part of thyroid cartilage by a potential space filled with fat - the pre-epiglottic space. The space may be invaded in carcinoma of supraglottic larynx or the base of tongue.

Reference: Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat &Head and Neck Surgery, PL Dhingra 7th edition; Page 319

questions.text: A 50 year old male presented with right sided reddish pink nasal mass and epistaxis. CT Scan image is given in the picture. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Complaints of epistaxis in a 50 year old male patient with right sided reddish pink nasal mass and CT showing mass in nasal cavity and maxilla with internal foci of calcifications suggests the diagnosis of inverted papilloma.

Inverted Papilloma (Transitional Cell Papilloma or Ringertz Tumour or Schneiderian Papilloma)

  • It is a tumour of the nonolfactory mucosa of nose (Schneiderian membrane) and paranasal sinuses.
  • Though benign, these lesions are locally invasive & commonly recur and are associated with squamous cell carcinoma.
  • Most common site of origin is lateral wall of nose in the middle meatus; less commonly it arises from the maxillary, frontal or sphenoid sinus
  • It is so named because hyperplastic papillomatous tissue grows into the stroma rather than in exophytic manner
  • Human papilloma virus is thought to be responsible for its aetiology.
  • Clinically, men are affected more than women in the age group of 40-70.
  • It is almost always unilateral and presents with nasal obstruction, nasal discharge and epistaxis.
  • It can invade sinuses or orbit. Orbital involvement causes proptosis, diplopia and lacrimation.
  • On nasal endoscopy, it presents as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polypus or polypi
  • Computed tomography (CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) show the location and extent of the lesion.
  • CT features include internal calcification, and bony erosion or bowing. Focal hyperostosis is a finding which has been said to correlate with the site of origin of this neoplasm - a finding which has potential relevance in planning the extent of surgery needed to achieve extirpation.
  • On MRI a characteristic convoluted, cerebrifrom pattern is said to be highly suggestive of this diagnosis, with the concomitant finding of necrosis suggesting a coexistent focus of carcinoma
  • MRI also helps to differentiate associated secretions in sinus from the actual tumour mass.
  • Biopsy is essential for diagnosis.
  • Care should be taken as simple nasal polypi may be associated with it or even the patient might have been operated for their removal.
  • Treatment: Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. It can be performed by lateral rhinotomy or sublabial degloving approach. These days endoscopic approach is preferred.
  • In 10-15% of cases, it is associated with malignancy.
  • Wider external surgical approaches may be required for tumour extending to the frontal sinus or orbit.
  • Recurrence can occur.
  • Radiotherapy is not advised as it may induce malignancy.

Other options:

  • Rhinosporidiosis: It is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by Rhinosporidium seeberi, more common in the southern states of India.
    • It mainly affects nose and nasopharynx. Nasal endoscopy: a leafy, polypoidal mass, pink to purple in colour and attached to nasal septum or lateral wall.
